Introduction

Point of Care Testing (POCT) is an established part of clinical practice offering, in many instances, the rapid and convenient provision of test results that can be of benefit to the patient. It is, however, a significant risk management issue for the trusts. Results obtained by non-specialist staff carry as much weight in patient management as results from sophisticated equipment in the care of professional laboratory staff. Incorrect results have the same health and legal implications, whatever their origin. The POCT Policy & Procedure has been put into place to minimise the risk to patients from inaccurate POCT results.

Pathology First is a joint venture between Southend University Hospital (SUH) and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals (BTUH) and iPP (Integrated Pathology Partnerships) Analytics. Day to day operational management of the POCT service is by staff employed by iPP Analytics. Clinical oversight and governance is provided through Trust Pathology Consultant staff.

Although there are variations in the POCT equipment available at each Trust, this document provides an over-arching policy for the introduction, use and management of POCT devices across both Trusts. The same clinical governance principles apply and there is a single laboratory POCT operational team responsible for day-to-day management of these devices.

Guidelines and/or standards for POCT have been issued by a number of organisations including the Department of Health, United Kingdom Accreditation Service, ISO and the MHRA. This policy aims to ensure that POCT at SUH and BTUH complies with all such advice and guidance.
Failure to comply with the policy will result in the removal of the instrument from the location.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to ensure reliable performance and management of the risks associated with testing outside the main laboratory by
Ensuring consistent procedures are in place throughout the Trusts
Ensuring that a high quality and cost-effective service is provided
Defining the organisation and management responsibilities so that the relevant issues are addressed systematically
Establishing a standardised approach to the introduction and implementation of any POCT device
The scope of this policy includes:
Managers and all users in all wards and clinical departments within SUH and BTUH who are using POCT devices for the diagnosis and treatment of patients.
All POCT equipment, whether the device is purchased, hired, loaned or received as a donation.
Existing equipment as well as new or replacement devices

For the purposes of this document, these devices include the whole range of items from simple dipstick tests to sophisticated analysers located outside the laboratory. It includes devices managed by Pathology First and those that are purchased/loaned/donated directly to or by the Trust(s).

To achieve the best possible results from these devices it is essential that there is a close liaison between the POCT and the Pathology departments within each Trust relating to all aspects of such tests.

The ISO standard “BS EN ISO 22870 POCT Requirements for quality and competence” states that this standard can also be applied to transcutaneous measurements, the analysis of expired air and in vivo monitoring of physiological parameters. For tests such as these, a liaison with POCT and Pathology is required.
Definitions & Abbreviations
The following abbreviations apply throughout this policy:

Basildon & Thurrock University's Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

For the purpose of this document, ‘Point of Care Testing' (POCT) is defined as the performance of analytical tests on patient specimens outside the laboratory by non-laboratory staff. The equipment used varies from simple dipstick tests to sophisticated analysers.

The Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) define Point of Care Testing (POCT) as an analytical test performed for a patient by a healthcare professional outside of the conventional laboratory setting.

For the purpose of this policy the word ‘device' is used to cover a whole range of items used outside the laboratory setting to perform analytical testing for a patient, from simple urine dipstick tests to sophisticated analysers.
This is a Pathology joint organisational venture between Basildon Hospital and Southend Hospital University Trusts and iPP Analytics.

The ‘user' is any person who handles the device to produce patient results, carry out maintenance or perform quality assurance checks. This includes Clinicians, Nursing staff, Healthcare Scientists and Service Engineers.
A staff member who has particular responsibility for coordinating the use of POCT in their area.
The clinical department or area in which a POCT device is located.
Quality Assurance (QA) is defined as a procedure or set of procedures intended to ensure that a product or service meets specified requirements.

Internal quality control (QC) is a means of determining that the POCT device is technically performing correctly at that specific time and that the patient result is reliable before it is released and acted on.

External quality assessment (EQA) is a means of determining how a particular POCT device is performing in comparison to similar devices at different sites and to other devices or other laboratory analysers.

Required for all new products subject to one or more European safety directives. A visible sign that the manufacturer of the product is checking conformity with all of the directives relating to the product.

Organisation & Governance

Clinical governance is a systematic approach to maintaining and improving the quality of patient care and controlling clinical risk. It is an essential part of the POCT service and is delivered through multidisciplinary POCT committees on each site. These committees are accountable to the Trusts Pathology Governance Committees. Representatives from the appropriate laboratory disciplines play a vital role in these groups which are chaired by a Pathology Consultant

Role & Responsibilities within the Trusts
4.2.1 Committees/Teams
Point of Care Testing Committee

The POCT committee is responsible for overseeing and co-ordinating all aspects of the POCT service within their Trust. Clinical Governance for POCT services is provided through the POCT policy. This policy is reviewed and updated every 2 years as a collaborative effort between committees at both Trusts.

The POCT group of multidisciplinary healthcare professionals meet at least 4 times per year to review and monitor quality indicators, ensure that the POCT policy is being followed and to table new POCT proposals for discussion. Additional members may be invited or co-opted depending on the needs of the group.
For POCT committee terms of reference, see appendix 1. The role of the POCT committee at each Trust is to:
Advise on current and future POCT within the Trust
Update and agree the POCT policy collaboratively across both Trusts every 2 years
Standardise practice across each Trust and, where appropriate, between Trusts
Encourage communication about POCT and sharing of expertise between disciplines
Review recent publications / guidelines on POCT and implement as required

Evaluate and approve the introduction of all new POCT equipment to be used throughout the Trust. Consideration is given to clinical need and effectiveness and should include a cost-benefit analysis (see section 5)
Co-ordinate POCT usage and development and ensure that methods introduced are appropriate, robust, rationalised and cost-effective
Ensure that POCT devices are implemented and used appropriately and that each POCT is undertaken safely and reliably
Ensure that an on-going reporting system is in place to investigate problems and to ensure that issues raised are reported to individual units and
escalated as appropriate
To monitor staff compliance with POCT equipment, training and performance in EQA schemes
To receive reports and resolve issues relating to POCT
To support the POCT operational team

The remit of the committee will cover all medical equipment that is used to perform analytical tests on patient specimens outside the laboratory by non-laboratory staff; regardless of cost, or their source of funding or supply.
Subgroups will be formed to work on specific areas of POCT as the need arises. Reports:

An Annual Management Report on POCT will be provided. The review will include the clinical need, the clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness of POCT. This will be presented to Pathology Clinical Governance.
POCT Operational Team

This team comprises of relevant personnel from Pathology First. Teams should be adequately resourced to enable them to implement and monitor compliance with the POCT policy and procedure. They are responsible for ensuring any recommendations imposed on the service by the committee are carried out.
Role of the POCT Operational Team
To contribute to and advise regarding any potential new

POCT service and the procurement of equipment, including an assessment of the clinical need, available options, suitability of equipment, required accuracy and precision, correlation with laboratory results, interpretation of results, maintenance requirements and backup service.
To advise on the Health and Safety aspects of POCT.
To advise that Standard Operating Procedures for all aspects of the testing process are documented in accordance with the requirements of the Clinical Pathology Accreditation body.
To advise on the internal quality control regimen and provide the materials unless otherwise specified.
To distribute material for external quality assurance testing, provide feedback reports to wards/departments and assist in investigating and resolving the reasons for poor performance.
To audit the routine operation, record-keeping and training requirements.
To liaise closely with wards/departments regarding the operation of the scheme and to detect problems early.
To check unexpected patient results.
To lend support as far as laboratory responsibilities will allow when instrument malfunction is suspected.
To provide a backup analytical service in case of failure of POCT equipment when a problem cannot be resolved immediately.
4.2.2 Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
Duties Are:
Chief Executive/Medical Director/Director of Nursing

As the accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring SUH and BTUH have robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Responsible for the implementation of this policy.
Clinical Director
Holds the ultimate responsibility for Point of Care Testing as guardian of Clinical Governance.
Advises and arbitrates if necessary if agreement about the introduction of a POCT service cannot be reached.
Ensures guidelines are in place for interpretation of results and further patient management.
Clinical Lead for POCT
Has clinical oversight for Point of Care Testing, liaising between the Trust and Pathology First on matters including current testing protocols and implementation of new equipment/ tests.
Holds the role of Chairperson of the Point of Care Testing Committee.
Reviews POCT EQA and reports upon it.
Heads of Nursing and Midwifery and Matrons
Heads of Nursing and Midwifery and Matrons have a responsibility to ensure correct procedures are followed.
Ward or Departmental Managers
To take on managerial ownership of any POCT equipment within their area and to ensure that it is maintained and used correctly.
They will ensure the competency of all users of POCT in their area. They will keep records of initial training, competency statements and update training.

If appropriate they will appoint a link person to oversee the day-to-day operation of POCT equipment within their area. The use of a Link Person does not absolve the ward/department manager of full responsibility for POCT

Where there has been an incident involving POCT devices, including inadequate performance or documentation of patient or Quality Assurance results, Ward or Departmental managers will investigate the incident and be responsible for reporting this to POCT. All such incidents should be brought to the attention of the POCT manager and the POCT committee.
Any request for new, upgraded or replacement POCT processes must be submitted to the POCT committee for approval. This includes free, trial and loan devices.
Point of Care Testing Link Person

A Link Person may be designated within a ward/department for the purpose of ensuring the day to day operation of POCT systems, ensuring equipment is functioning and necessary consumables are available. They may provide cascade training, having been trained to a high level of competence, ensuring staff undertaking POCT are suitable to do so.
Pharmacy

Pharmacy is responsible for standardising, ordering and supplying the majority of POCT consumables as directed by the POCT committee. Pathology First are responsible for standardising, ordering and supplying all blood gas consumables.
POCT Operations Manager & Team Manager

The POCT service managers monitor the POCT service within each Trust. They ensure that POCT policies and procedures are adhered to and that adequate resources and support from Pathology First are available to facilitate a safe and reliable service.
Clinicians
To identify areas of clinical need where the introduction of POCT could be appropriate and provide the information necessary for the cost-benefit analysis (See Appendix 2).
To approach POCT in the spirit of the policy and not to attempt to introduce new testing without referring to the POCT policy.
To undertake POCT themselves only after adequate training and certification.
To be familiar with the information provided by and shortcomings of the POCT results that they use for their patient management.
To ensure that results of POCT are recorded accurately, unequivocally and safely and that information about tests upon which they base patient management decisions can be retrieved in retrospect.
The responsibility for patient results obtained using POCT and therapeutic decisions based on those results lies with the requesting clinician for the ward/department.
All Users

The individual conducting the analysis is accountable for the results they generate using POCT devices. They must ensure their POCT training is up to date and that their competence is maintained. It is the responsibility of the user:

To follow procedures as set out in the documented Standard Operating Procedure, including sample taking and handling, instrument checks and/or Quality Control, recording of results and disposal of consumables.
To undertake and record External Quality Control analysis as required.

To report suspect Quality Control results or possible instrument malfunction immediately to the Link person or person in charge at the time and to stop using the equipment until the matter has been resolved.
To report abnormal or suspect patient results to the responsible person immediately
To report adverse incidents related to POCT devices to the Link nurse where used and to the POCT team.
Procedure
Requests for new equipment/ tests
All requests for new POCT devices/ tests are to be made in line with the following procedure:
Health and Safety
All POCT devices must comply with current health and safety legislation and guidance and with the relevant Trust infection control policy.
All users of POCT equipment must comply with all the current Trust Health and Safety Policies.
A COSHH assessment must be carried out and safety data sheets for all relevant substances recorded.
Samples, spillages and waste from instruments must be treated in accordance with the Trust's Infection Control Policies.
A completed decontamination certificate must be issued before servicing or repair of equipment commences. The procedure for decontamination must be included in the SOP.
Standard universal precautions such as hand decontamination, wearing of appropriate clothing, disposal of sharps and waste should be employed by staff using devices.
Standard Operating Procedure
An SOP, using the appropriate Trust template, must be produced prior to the POCT equipment being used. It must be available to and followed by all users of the device
The SOP must be available for all users of the device to reference on the Intranet. It will be reviewed every two years and available to accreditation agency inspectors.
The document should include, but not be limited to:
Instructions for use of the device, including simple troubleshooting and safe working practice
Interpretation of error messages
Normal ranges and action to take when a result is obtained (normal or abnormal)
Recording of data – QC and results
Relevant IQC and EQA procedures
Decontamination procedures
Who has responsibility and authority to withdraw a device from service and action to be taken if the device fails
The POCT team will regularly review the SOP but the clinical unit using the POCT equipment will be responsible for regular review as it reflects their current practice,
Training Requirements

All staff involved in POCT must be trained and competent in the use of POCT devices. Link Persons play a vital role in this process. Many vendors have established training programmes, which they will modify and help deliver to suit local needs. Advantage could be taken of e-learning programmes. Wherever possible, POCT instruments should be password protected and only accessible by certified users.
The training and certification of POCT users should be overseen and monitored by the ward managers. Update training may be required to maintain a high standard of performance.
POCT staff training programmes should include:
Instructions on safe working practices
Principles of operation of the POCT device
Review of the manufacturer's instructions for use, limitations of the device and the interpretation of results
Review and understanding of error messages, interpretation and appropriate responses
Calibration and quality control requirements, to include performance, appropriate record keeping and required actions for failed results
Patient preparation, sample collection and handling according to health and safety regulations and the manufacturers stated requirements
Appropriate responses to and recording of patient results
Facilitating the assignment of operator identification numbers to trained POCT
users
Inclusion in the register of certified trained users and notification of the programme for retraining and monitoring
Action on improper and unsafe use of a POCT device
Procedure for recording adverse incidents with a POCT device
Managers are responsible for maintaining a full record of training, which must be made available for inspection upon request.
It is the responsibility of the user to ensure that they are competent to use any POCT device.
Monitoring and Audit
Quality Assurance Programme

Quality assurance is an integral component of any POCT service and includes all the measures taken to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the patient result. It is important that all POCT devices are included in a quality assurance programme and that this is operational prior to patient testing at each site. Elements of quality assurance include:
Performance and documentation of appropriate quality control and/or calibration
Correct patient identification
Selection of the appropriate test
Obtaining a satisfactory sample and sample integrity
The suspension/withdrawal of any POCT service in the event of a safety issue as directed by the POCT/ ward managers
Performance of the test in accordance with the manufacturer's instruction
Correct interpretation of the result and appropriate action taken
Recording of the test result in the patient record
Internal Quality Control (IQC)

The SOP for each POC device must outline IQC requirements which must follow the instrument manufacturer's guidelines. It must outline the material to be used, specify the frequency at which the IQC is performed and define the acceptable limits for the QC prior to testing a patient sample.

All POCT users should be educated as to the essential requirement for the QC procedures, appropriate action to take in the event of substandard QC, and the implications when QC is not performed according to the procedure.
Investigations for which no QC procedures are available should be reviewed by the POCT committee with the aim of replacement with suitable quality-controlled alternatives.
External Quality Assessment (EQA)

The SOP for each POCT device must outline EQA requirements. A sample is issued by a coordinating Laboratory for analysis by a user of the instrument, as if it were a normal patient sample. The value should be recorded and returned to the coordinating laboratory which will collate and objectively evaluate the information from all the test sites. It will then inform the test sites of their comparative performance. Issues of poor performance may be addressed via the appropriate Ward Manager and Link Person, together with the POCT Team Manager.

Non-compliance regarding a clinical unit's EQA participation will be defined as an EQA return rate of <75% or poor performance >25% in a 12 month period, 2 consecutive non-returns or 2 consecutive poor EQA results. Non-compliance will result in ward monitoring for 6 months by the POCT Team. If the Ward's performance does not improve the POCT device will be removed from the Ward and samples for the test in question will need to be sent to the Pathology Laboratory for analysis. The Clinical Unit Managers and Business Unit will be informed.
Maintenance and Service

The maintenance and service of POCT devices is essential to ensure a functional, robust and reliable POCT service. Managers should identify persons to be responsible for the day-to-day care of POCT devices. All such maintenance and servicing should be conducted in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions
The day to day maintenance of a POCT device must ensure:
That the device is kept in good and safe working order. Good stock control of all reagents, consumables and controls within their shelf-life

The temporary withdrawal of any device/test from the POCT service that is not performing to the manufacturer's specification, ensuring that it is not used again until the appropriate remedial action has been taken and that the POCT committee has been informed
The suspension/withdrawal of any POCT service in the event of a safety issue as directed by the POCT/Ward managers.
Recording Results and Audit Trail
It is vital that all patient results allow full traceability:

All patient and Quality Control/Quality Assessment (QC/QA) results must be recorded. This record must include unequivocal patient identity, time of test, the result, relevant QC results and the identity of the user.

The mechanism for the transfer of results from the device to the patient's record must be unambiguous and stated in the SOP. Results from thermal printouts must be transcribed because the print fades.

All patients' results must be treated as confidential and kept in a secure place. The storage of results should be in line with that maintained within the laboratory and compatible with RCPath guidelines.
Pathology staff and individuals identified by the POCT committee must have free access to QC/QA results.
Maintenance/ Incident Records

A maintenance and incident log book should be maintained for each POCT device to record details of maintenance, faults, repairs and corrective action by named individuals. The POCT Team and Ward Managers are responsible for responding to issues logged and recording the corrective actions taken in this log book. Such actions may be electronically recorded.
Pathology staff and individuals identified by the POCT committee must have free access to log books.
Log books should be retained for the lifetime of the equipment or a minimum of 10 years.
Retention of Records

Records of instrument maintenance, faults and corrective action, training records, quality control records and medical records should all be retained for the length of time specified in RCPath Guidelines.
Connectivity

Connectivity between disparate computer systems and POCT analysers is an essential component for provision of an effective POCT service within an organisation. In particular, it allows POCT devices to be controlled and managed centrally and facilitates exchange of information from the remote POCT site to the laboratory/hospital information system
Key IT connectivity goals are:
Positive identification of patient samples and patient demographics to the system.
Operator ID to allow traceability of results. Ideally staff member's barcoded staff ID card or similar device should be used.
Audit controls, logs and accountability.
Password protected access to the system, login procedures and monitoring, and automatic logoff settings.
Ability to distinguish POCT results from other results on the Laboratory Information System.
Integration of all results generated from POCT devices with the laboratory information system and appropriate clinical information systems.
Generation of positively identified hard copy of results.
Appropriate data storage and back up.
Remote monitoring of POCT QC and device performance from the clinical
laboratory.
Remote ability to temporarily block certified individuals who are not conforming to the stated QC protocol.
On board decision support for order entry and interpretation tailored to the analyser and particular test
Checking for data integrity.
Competence/Proficiency Testing of Users
Competence/proficiency testing is supplemental to the standard laboratory quality assurance measures. All operators must be assessed before being given access to Point of Care equipment.
Audit

All Clinical Unit managers are responsible for monitoring the POCT equipment in their area. They must ensure that POCT policy is followed on a day to day basis. The POCT team will perform audits on the use of POCT equipment and report their findings to the appropriate Clinical Unit Manager, Matron and governance leads. A copy will also be sent to the Director of Nursing, Infection control, Risk and Litigation and the POCT committee.

Appendix 1: POCT Committee Terms of Reference Definition
Point of Care Testing (POCT) is defined as any analytical test performed for a patient by a healthcare professional outside the conventional laboratory.
Membership
Chairman (Clinical Lead for POCT)
POCT Operations manager
POCT Team Manager
Associate Practitioner POCT
Pathology Quality Manager
Nominated representation from all specialist areas undertaking POCT and those areas who support POCT
Others by invitation only may be co-opted as necessary
Accountability
The POCT committee will be accountable to the Pathology Governance Committee and through them to the Trust Board.
Aims and Objectives
The Point of Care Testing (POCT) Committee aims to improve the clinical risk management and clinical effectiveness of point of care testing by:
Encouraging communication about POCT and the sharing of expertise between disciplines
Discussing and endorsing a Trust-Wide POCT policy for the management, implementation and control of POCT
To inform the Chief Executive and relevant Clinical Director/ Governance lead for any area with persistent non-compliance with the POCT policy through Operational Risk management Group
Determining the need for POCT equipment at particular locations
Standardising practice across the Trust
Approving or modifying POCT applications
Reviewing written procedures for POCT equipment
Reviewing POCT-related adverse incidents
Monitoring and evaluation (via feedback from ward managers and clinicians in areas using POCT equipment) of:
Reviewing adequacy of record keeping for all POCT applications for training and equipment
Identifying and remedying poor performance of POCT applications

Receiving and determining action on deficiencies in the internal quality control, external quality assurance, documentation or practice brought to its attention through the above mechanisms or any other source
Addressing any POCT performance issues
Reviewing recent publications/ guidelines on POCT and implement as required

Provide an annual report to the Clinical Director of Pathology, and via Clinical Assurance Committee to the Trust Board. The review will include the clinical need, the clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness of POCT
Constitution
The Chair-person will be a Consultant Clinical Biochemist or POCT manager.
The position may be reviewed by the Pathology Clinical Director
Members will be selected to represent a wide range of areas of the Trust who are involved and interested in POCT. Representatives may be nominated by the chair person
Members should have a nominated deputy to attend in their absence and their combined attendance should remain >75% in a 12 month period
The group may co-opt members with the approval of the Chairperson and a majority vote at a committee meeting
When an urgent decision is required on any POCT application the chairperson, POCT manager and relevant Consultant may make the decision under delegated powers
A quorum is six members, one of which must be the Chairperson or a POCT Manager and two must be non-pathology staff members
Meetings will be held quarterly
Constitution to be reviewed annually
Agenda
Standing items will be:
a)Formal requests for use of POCT instruments and kits b)Recent guidelines and publications pertinent to POCT c)POCT performance issues
d)External quality assurance issues
e)POCT related incident report forms
f)Annual audit schedule
g)POCT training
h)POCT feedback i) Awareness of POCT
j)IT issues
Appendix 2: POCT Assessment of Needs Form
PROPOSAL FOR INTRODUCTION OF POINT OF CARE TESTING (POCT) DEVICE(S)

The proposal form is designed to allow the safe introduction of POCT devices and processes. It will ensure that relevant issues have been covered, that appropriate support is available and that efforts are not duplicated. There must be a commitment from the department to meet all regulatory requirements and that staff are available to work with the POCT team for initial set up and implementation and for the ongoing daily running of the device
Introduction of all new POCT devices must be approved by the Trust POCT Committee and are subject to financial approval by the appropriate Trust authority.
